title: tributes-paid-alan-hay-fondly-known-mr-musselburgh
story: Known affectionately as ldquoMr Musselburgh, he served for many years on Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council and is a former chairman of the Fisherrow Trust.Irene Tait, chairperson of Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council, said members were ldquosaddened to hear of his recent death.ldquoAlan was a member of the community council for many years, serving as both treasurer and vice-chairman, she said.ldquoHe was a man who served the town well because he cared so deeply about it and always went that extra mile to help others.ldquoAlan will be a great loss to all of us.ldquoOur thoughts are with his family and friends at this sad time.Mr Hay, who was born in Fisherrow, was a former chairman of the Fisherrow Trust, which oversaw a former school on South Street being turned into a centre for community and local organisations.He was also a former committee member of Eskmuthe Rowing Club, which brought coastal rowing to Musselburgh.Mr Hay was the cousin of the late golf commentator Alex Hay, who was educated at Musselburgh Grammar School.Councillor Stuart Currie, Musselburgh ward member, said: ldquoI was saddened to learn of the passing of Alan Hay. Alan was a real community stalwart for Musselburgh and never missed an opportunity to make the case for improvements in our town.ldquoHis contribution to the community council was enormous and I know he was well regarded by his colleagues.ldquoI extend my condolences to Alanrsquos family and many friends.Fellow Musselburgh councillor John Williamson said: ldquoI was saddened to hear about Alanrsquos passing.ldquoI first knew Alan from his long involvement with Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council.ldquoAlan was involved in so many matters to do with Musselburgh, always with the aim of improving the lives of its citizens. Alan was quite rightly referred to as lsquoMr Musselburghrsquo.ldquoHe will be sorely missed by all who knew him personally and through all of his efforts for the town. My sympathies go to his loved ones.

title: barry-shields-caught-carrying-baseball-bat-tranent-high-street
story: Barry Shields, , was spotted by police officers carrying the makesht weapon on the townrsquos High Street.Shields, of Caponhall Drive, was arrested and charged with being in possession of an offensive weapon.He pleaded guilty to the charge at an earlier hearing at Edinburgh Sherf Court and sentence had been deferred for him to be of good behaviour.He ed to the dock on Monday, where Sherf Peter McCormack was told there had been no further reports made to police concerning Shields.The sherf was content to admonish Shields.Shields admitted possessing the baseball bat while in public at High Street, Tranent, on April , .

title: brunton-putting-filmed-rapunzel-pantomime-christmas
story: The Brunton in Musselburgh has had to postpone its performance of Aladdin until next year due to coronavirus restrictions.Instead, a specially filmed version of Rapunzel is being created to keep everyone entertained over the Christmas season.Writer and director John Binnie said: ldquoThe story of Rapunzel, with its themes of isolation and the importance of friendships, are relevant today as we navigate our way through the Covid- pandemic.ldquoRapunzel ndash A Pantomime Film for all the Family has been created for the many schoolchildren and families who have missed out on their visit to the pantomime at The Brunton this year.The Brunton has brought together the creative team behind last yearrsquos pantomime Cinderella and film makers D Fie Foe to create Rapunzel.Designed by Robin Mitchell, with musical direction by Tommy Travers, the pantomime film promises songs and slapstick, local references and colourful characters.Welcomed back are Brunton favourites Graham Crammond as the Dame, Wendy Seager as the Sorceress, Eildih Weir as Rapunzel and Ross Donnachie as Jammy.The film will be available to schools and families to view online during December. It can be watched online on December - and December -January , with screenings planned at The Brunton on December , , , ,  and .

title: letter-week-action-make-a1-safer-needed-now
story: This has been as a member of the public, Dunbar community councillor and East Lothian councillor for Dunbar and East Linton ward from  to .My concerns have long been echoed by members of the public, local groups and local community councils along the A corridor.I have been a long-standing attendee at the A Action Group Meetings, where concerns about the A have been raised ndash particularly the need for dualling and improvements to junction safety, including lighting, speed restriction and construction of on off access.Over the years, the meetings have been told of improvements in Berwickshire, including LED catrsquos eyes and improved junctions.Investment has been made in the west of East Lothian. However, requests for improvements around Dunbar have not been successful.Reasons for refusal include not a bad enough fatal accident history, and that the cost of lighting LED catrsquos eyes junction upgrade is too expensive.The action group last met in December . After requests to East Lothian Council, it is due to meet again on Friday.Throughout , requests have been made to Transport Scotland by Dunbar and West Barns community councils and Hallhill TRA for a meeting to discuss the junction safety at Belhaven.Iain Gray MSP has also had correspondence with the Transport Minister.Transport Scotland did meet with ELC officers in June  but community members did not find out until afterwards.The concerns of local residents need to be heard. It is local residents who use the roads on a daily basis and can speak from experience.Richard Perry, of Transport Scotland, has offered an online discussion later in November. This is to be welcomed.It is essential that Transport Scotland engages with local communities in East Lothian who have concerns about safety along the A.The local population is increasing and this is putting added pressure on the A corridor. During , proposals have been made for further developments around Dunbar, which will add to traffic both on the trunk road and at the already busy access points from the town. These include  Taylor Wimpey houses at Hallhill North, DunBear Park and the Viridor plastics recycling facility at Oxwellmains.As noted above, past representations to Transport Scotland have been met too frequently by the response that the areas of concern do not have a signicant fatal accident record.There have been fatalities and serious injuries over the years.It should not take others to be hurt before investment is made to make the road safer.Jacquie BellBelhaven

title: decision-planned-house-gifford-garden-not-popularity-contest
story: Councillor Norman Hampshire, convenor of East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee, slapped down colleagues who asked members to refuse permission for the house to be built in garden grounds of a cottage in Gford.Local ward councillors Shamin Akhtar and Craig Hoy both called for the committee to refuse the plans after calling them in because of the number of objections and concerns over the size of the proposed house.But Mr Hampshire told them: ldquoWe take decisions on planning policy, not popularity.The committee heard that plans to build the new house in the grounds of Garden Cottage, at the junction of Edinburgh Road and Tweeddale Avenue, had received  objections from residents.Gford Community Council raised concerns about the size of the proposed three-bedroom house, which was described as one-and-a-half storeys high with ldquoadditional single-storey and two-storey components.Representing neighbours living in Orchard Cottage ndash which was granted planning permission to be built in a nearby garden six years ago ndash Derek Scott described the planned house as being ldquoshoe-horned into a narrow plot. He said the owners of the neighbouring cottage objected to the impact it would have on their privacy, with three windows in particular overlooking their garden.However, council officers said a condition had been included in planning permission to ensure that one of the windows ndash on the first floor ndashwould be obscured.Mr Scott told the committee: ldquoOpaque windows only provide privacy when they are closed.He argued that the new house was not in keeping with the character of Gford Conservation Area, adding: ldquoIt is more akin to a modern housing estate.Councillor Jeremy Findlay said he believed the size of the house was ldquooverdevelopment of the site.He said: ldquoI do not feel it is in keeping with the surrounding properties.Mr Hampshiredisagreed, saying: ldquoI do not believe it is an overdevelopment of the site: it has large gardens to the front and rear, far bigger than most other properties in East Lothian.The planning committee decided by eight votes to three to approve the planning application.

title: coronavirus-east-lothian-council-fund-support-community-groups
story: Applications to One Council Partnership Funding are open until the end of the month, with the money to be used to support community resilience efforts during the global pandemic.The funding could be used to help cover the running costs and volunteer expenses for community projects, charities and third-sector organisations.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, cabinet spokesman for community wellbeing, encouraged groups to apply.He said: ldquoIrsquom pleased to announce the launch of this next round of council funding for community groups for  .ldquoWe have seen this year, more than ever, the real dference volunteers and community groups can make.ldquoMany of the organisations which have received One Council Partnership Funding have played a vital role in helping people affected by Covid during this challenging time.Already, Cockenzie-based Heavy Sound East Lothian Foodbank The Ridge in Dunbar North Berwick Youth Project and Recharge in Tranent have benefited from the fund.Groups looking to secure funding will be required to prioritise at least one of the following themes: promoting digital inclusion addressing domestic abuse supporting vulnerable children and young people reducing poverty including food initiatives mental health and wellbeing, including social isolation, and supporting volunteering.For more information, go to www.eastlothian.gov.uk

title: plans-flats-former-dance-school-haddington
story: Haddington School of Dance and Music was forced to close its doors earlier this year ldquodue to the combination of the coronavirus pandemic and the ongoing repair cost of our beautul old building.A spokeswoman for the dance school, which was based on Haddingtonrsquos Newton Port, said: ldquoWe want to thank everyone who has been a part of our company, taken classes with us, supported us and has helped make the school a wonderful environment over the past  years.It is the second time that plans have been lodged with East Lothian Council to see the building, which dates back to , brought back to le.The original plans highlighted a range of issues relating to the increasing costs, with money being used on the necessary modernisation of heating, lighting and plumbing, while vandals had stolen lead from the roof.The spokeswoman said the financial losses were ldquoentirely due to the upkeep of the building.In January, proposals for four flats were revealed but they were withdrawn three months later.Now, Mr P Black has lodged fresh plans with the local authorityrsquos planning department.If approved, his proposals would see the modern extensions ndash the music room, second dance hall and coffee bar ndash at the rear of the building removed.The conversion would see accommodation created over two levels inside the building, which was originally opened as St Johnrsquos Church of Scotland in  before being bought by the dance school nine years ago.On the ground floor, there would be two two-bedroom flats, with a three-bedroom flat upstairs.A planning statement included in the latest application highlights that efforts have been made over the last six months to find someone to take on the building in its current form.It reads: ldquoWe made enquiries with McEwan Fraser, who indicate the property is under offer and attracted some market interest.ldquoHowever, none of the market interest was for the ongoing use as a community hall and the feedback from interested parties was the costs to retain the building form and uses with the repairs required would be prohibitive to securing a viable sale.The developers noted that a number of churches have been transformed into homes and called on East Lothian Council to follow along that line.A decision on the proposals is expected before Christmas.

title: letters-sent-youths-homes-disorder-cockenzie-port-seton
story: Police officers have been working alongside East Lothian Council community wardens following a rise in complaints about youth-related anti-social behaviour in the area.Incidents have included buses being damaged by youngsters throwing objects at them.Enquiries are continuing in a bid to identy those responsible for the disorder.On Thursday, November , a spokesman for Police Scotland said: ldquoYesterday, the enquiry team identied and charged two youths with a number of offences committed over the past week.ldquoThirteen other youths, identied as being within the group causing disorder, will be getting letters sent home from the anti-social behaviour team.ldquoShould these youths become involved in disorder again, there are processes where we can escalate the action beyond what has been taken.ldquoOur enquiry team have positive lines of enquiry in relation to other offences and more youths will be traced and charged in the coming days.Officers have been assigned to deal with disorder in Cockenzie and Port Seton on a daily basis, with national officers also being drafted in to work alongside them and community wardens.The spokesman added: ldquoWe are committed to dealing with this issue and will take a zero-tolerance approach.Anyone with any information regarding anti-social behaviour should contact police on  or Crimestoppers on   .

title: community-groups-unite-opposition-goshen-farm-housing-plans
story: Developers Barratt David Wilsonhave lodged an appeal with Scottish Ministers three years after applying for planning permission in principle to build the houses at Goshen Farm, on the eastern edge of Musselburgh.However,Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council, and Prestonpans Community Council have both objected to the housing, pointing to traffic problems surrounding the towns, the need to protect the green belt and a lack of GP services.Nearly  private objections have been lodged with the Reporter from local residents, with concerns about the impact on Musselburgh Primary Care Centre, the only GP centre in the countyrsquos biggest town, at the forefront of concerns.The centre, which combines two practices, has nearly , patients on its book and is under pressure.Local councillors earlier called on the local authority to write to NHS Lothian and ScottishHealth Minster Jeane Freeman MSP to ask for a new GP surgery to be built at Wallyford, where hundreds of new houses are being built.Appealing to the Reporter, Irene Tait, Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council chairperson, said: ldquoOur health service is at breaking point, and this started long before Covid-.ldquoOne of ourGP surgeries has over , patients registered, and they struggle to answer the phone, with theresult some patients give up and go straight to AE in Edinburgh.Mrs Tait also pointed to the pressures on rail services in the town, where the rush-hour ScotRail services have earned the nickname the ldquoSardine Express due to overcrowding in recent years.She added: ldquoHouses are sold on the goodinfrastructure we have in Musselburghthe reality is you are very luckyyou get standing room on the train in the morning and evening at rush hour, with lots of people left waiting for nextarrivals. Brian Weddell, Prestonpans Community Council chairperson, also pointed to health services, saying: ldquoThere is no health centre in Wallyford and the existing health services are struggling to managecurrent service levels.He pointed out that Goshen Farm as a housing site was removed from East Lothian Councilrsquos Local Development Plan after public consultation saw people come out against its inclusion.Concern about losing the green belt land which lies between the two towns was raised by both community councils.Mr Weddell said: ldquoIf this planning application is approved it will be another nail in the coffinof the green belt in East Lothian which is part of the wider Edinburgh green belt.ldquoIts purpose is to maintain the setting, character and identity of Edinburgh and its neighbouring settlements, and can take a number of forms, including wedges, corridors and buffers between settlements.ldquoIt shouldcontinue to have an important role in protecting the landscape setting of Musselburgh Inveresk and thewestern edges of Prestonpans and Tranent and in ensuring that residents have access to open spaces and the countryside.

title: newhailes-house-bosses-slam-youths-broke-snack-van
story: A post on the Musselburgh attractionrsquos Facebook page highlighted they were ldquodisappointed after the Doocot Diner was broken into at about .pm on Monday, November .According to the post on social media: ldquoAlthough the two youths were disturbed, they ran off before we could call the police.ldquoWe have good photographic and video evidence, which we will post as soon as Police Scotland have authorised us to .ldquoWe have absolutely no doubt that the two will be identied and caught.ldquoItrsquos been a long year for us all and when we are facing a tough few years, itrsquos sad that people have chosen to steal from a charity.ldquoThank you to Police Scotland for their attendance.The Palladian mansion, in the west of the town, was once home to the influential Dalrymple family, who gave the house its rococo interiors and collections of paintings, ceramics and furniture, along with the signicant th-century designed landscape.In the mid-s, Sir David Dalrymple built a library wing to hold his vast collection of , books, pamphlets, broadsheets, prints, maps and music books.The venue, managed and maintained by the National Trust for Scotland, sits in  hectares of historic landscape.Police confirmed enquiries into the incident were ongoing and anyone with information should contact Police Scotland on .

title: tranent-swimmers-take-loony-dook-december
story: On December , a group of the clubrsquos members will be braving the chilly winter weather and embarking on a loony dook in East Lothianrsquos coastal waters.A loony dook typically takes place on New Yearrsquos Day and sees members of the public take a dip in freezing cold waters, such as the Firth of Forth. Some people take part in swimming gear and others wear fancy dress, which is what the swimming club will be doing.The club had four options for fancy dress ndash Christmas, animals, superheroes and ballet dancers ndash and asked members of the public to suggest a fth, with a Wherersquos Wally theme being chosen now added to the selection.The public will then decide what theme of fancy dress the club will use.Rather than donate to the club, for example through an online fundraising page, people will sponsor their preferred fancy dress option.The option with the highest donations will be selected.More information and details of the loony dook will be released soon.

title: prestonpans-band-rahs-seek-support-release-debut-album
story: The Rahrsquos were planning to release When Does It Become Real  earlier this year but saw their musical ambitions put on hold by coronavirus.Now, the five-piece band, who went to Preston Lodge High School, have launched a kickstarter campaign, calling on fans to make a donation in exchange for rewards including a live performance in a fanrsquos living room!Jack McLeod, lead singer and rhythm guitarist, told the Courier how it had been a strange year for everyone.He said: ldquoWe were going to go with the release of the album and release of the singles as it progressed. That was due to kick off in April or May with the album release.ldquoThere was also going to be a tour, beginning in Newcastle, then Glasgow, Aberdeen and Edinburgh.ldquoWe were due to do that in April to tie in with the album release but it was postponed until July but again that has now been moved back.Now, the band, which started out playing Oasis and Arctic Monkeys covers in The Dasher and Prestonpans Labour Club, are looking to their fanbase to support their album release.Jack said: ldquoWe are in no way begging for your money, pulling your heartstrings or sitting feeling sorry for ourselves instead, we are getting this album over the line.ldquoIn March , we will be releasing When Does It Become Real  and we are offering people products via this Kickstarter project to simply gather the funds needed to get this album over the line.ldquoWith zero income as a band since February, we really are limited in our options. Instead of setting up a GoFundMe page and pleading poverty, we are selling our product and merchandise in a pre-order form.Already, more than pound, of the pound, target has been raised. And, depending on the amount donated, people can receive ious rewards. A payment of pound gets a digital download of the full -track album, while pound receives a t-shirt along with the album.A pledge of pound or more will receive a signed -inch vinyl and merchandise bundle, including album, t-shirt, tote bag, badges, bottle opener, lighter and stickers, while a donation of pound gets the buyer a live performance in their home, anywhere in the UK.Jack, along with bandmates Neale Gray , Jordan McIntyre , Lee Brownand Jack Miller , have also found rehearsals halted by the pandemic.Jack, who works as an electrician, said: ldquoWe practise twice a week and not even seeing the boys twice a week has been proper hard.For more information, go to www.kickstarter projects therahs the-rahs-debut-album-when-does-it-become-real

title: co-op-funding-boost-cockenzie-port-seton-bloom-project
story: The grouprsquos lsquoSeed to Platersquo initiative is in the next round of the Co-op Local Community Fund.However, the amount of money that the group receives will depend on the number of people who select it for the award.The funding round started on October  and will run for  months until October , .During this time, Co-op members will be able to select the project as their cause through their online account.The more members who select it, the more money it will receive.Those who are not a Co-op member and would like to support the project can join in their local store or online.The Local Community Fund supports projects across the UK. Every time a customer buys a selected Co-op branded product or shopping bag, a portion of the sale is donated to local causes. A portion is also given back to the shopper and the project of their choice.Sheila Chambers, secretary of Cockenzie and Port Seton In Bloom, said that the group was ldquodelighted its Seed to Plate project had been chosen but had no idea who had put the scheme forward.The project, which it was hoped would regenerate parts of the area, came to le though funding from Historic Environment Scotland and the local area partnership the In Bloom group received the funding last November.Many of the schemersquos plans had to be changed due to Covid- and the subsequent lockdown earlier this year.Since then, a iety of initiatives and projects have been completed, with two co-ordinators appointed to oversee proceedings with the initiative.An outdoor garden was created at Cockenzie Primary School to grow fruit and vegetables as part of an education programme.The food grown was distributed, along with recipe cards, to families across the local area.In addition, families in East Lothian who received free meals and food support were given seeds and plants to grow at home.Sunflower seeds were also given out as part of a competition.Lately, pumpkins were grown in the garden and donated to the school, and a recipe book is due to be published, featuring ways in which people can use the produce grown in their own gardens.It is hoped that the project can continue next year and fulfil its original plans should the appropriate funding be sourced.

title: prestonpans-gp-unable-return-job-contracting-coronavirus
story: Dr Amy Small announced her departure last month on the health centrersquos website, saying the decision had been made ldquowith huge sadness.The message continued: ldquoI am devastated to be unable toto my beloved practice and work and deeply saddened that I have not been able to say any form of farewell to any of my patients, given my sudden onset illness and unforeseen departure now.ldquoThe last  years have been an absolute joy ndash and I am very proud of what we have achieved together as a practice in supporting the health and wellbeing of our local population. It has been a privilege to be your GP.ldquoAs I continue to suffer from the ongoing symptoms of what is now recognised as lsquoLong Covidrsquo, I do not know what my own future holds.ldquoIn the first instance, my priority will be to hopefully recover my own physical health over time ndash and then to be able to resume my vocation in due course.ldquoAs the second wave of Covid- unfolds, I urge you all to take great care, follow the guidance in staying safe ndash and to look after those you love. I will miss you all, and want to thank you from the bottom of my heart for your messages of kindness during my sickness absence, and for your trust in my care as your GP over the last decade.Angela Stirling, practice manager, said: ldquoWe are saddened that, after a prolonged period of illness, Dr Small was unable toto work at the practice.ldquoThe remaining team continue to work hard to provide safe and effective care for the Prestonpans community through these dficult times.

title: backing-plans-27-flats-near-dunbar-town-centre
story: Plans for  new flats in the grounds of a former manse were welcomed by the group at their recent meeting.The proposals are the third phase of a development on the site, with  flats, immediately to the east, already in place.A further set of plans to transform the former manse at  Bayswell Road, which was previously home to CrossReach ndash which offers care to people of all ages ndash into four apartments also has the green light.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of Dunbar Community Council, said: ldquoWe all recognise we need houses that are financially accessible to people.ldquoI think the development beside it is very attractive andit is along those lines then it will be a real asset.ldquoPlainly, the CrossReach building itself is past its useful time as a single house.The latest proposals show a courtyard development made up of four separate buildings, with an amenity space at the heart of the site.The  new properties would be spread across the four buildings, which would be made up of three storeys.Three of the flats would be one-bedroom properties, with the remaining  flats featuring two bedrooms, which would be split into three dferent styles.Mrs Swan was joined by fellow community councillors in backing the latest scheme from Whiteadder Developments Ltd.The chairwoman added: ldquoThe more people who live within walking distance of the butcher and baker, the more trade on High Street.A planning statement included within the new application said the proposals offered ldquoa considered and exciting response offering considerable planning good to the area.It added: ldquoTo conclude, this proposal responds to the shortage of affordable housing and provides  new apartments which are conveniently located in close proximity to Dunbar town centre.

title: four-members-family-working-together-dunbar-asda
story: Section leader Denise Hitchcock, , works alongside her sister Joanne Turnbull and her two sons, Ryan and Alex Hitchcock Alex is the most recent family member to join the team.However, the connection does not stop there, as Denisersquos husband Michael is also an Asda colleague and works in The Jewel store, Edinburgh.Denise started at Asda Derby  years ago before moving to Asda Dunbar  years ago she now works in the ambient section.She said: ldquoItrsquos really nice working alongside Ryan ndash most of the time!ldquoSometimes we have disagreements, but it definitely is all part of the fun.ldquoHe works in the warehouse, so with me being on the ambient section I do see him quite a lot.ldquoHersquos a really good worker all round, and Irsquom really proud of him.ldquoAs for my sister Joanne, we look nothing alike, but everyone says we sound the same. Customers say they canrsquot tell us apart when we are talking!ldquoItrsquos really nice having my sister work alongside me. Itrsquos so good to have someone you can go toyou need a chat.Deen Rasul, store manager, enjoyed working alongside Denise, Joanne, , Ryan, , and -year-old Alex. He said: ldquoAlthough itrsquos not uncommon to have members of the same family working within our Asda family, itrsquos fairly unique to have so many working together at the same time.ldquoDespite being from the same family Jo, Denise and Ryan are all very much their own people with their own personalities and all play a crucial role in our store team.ldquoI look forward to working with Alex now too!

title: funding-scheme-set-support-local-families-haddington
story: Haddingtonrsquos community council has been at the heart of a new project designed to help families and iniduals struggling during the crisis.Pat Lemmon, from the townrsquos community council, encouraged people to come forward and stressed that all referrals would be dealt with ldquoin the strictest confidence.Referrals can be made by either a professional or agency working with an inidual or family who are experiencing financial dficulties and need a helping hand to purchase food or clothing.Mrs Lemmon said it would be ldquofoolish to think people were not struggling and in need of food and clothing.She said: ldquoYou are always going to have a situation where people get into financial dficulty and have to beg, steal or borrow to get a pair of shoes for their child.ldquoIt is not the child who should suffer.ldquoYou are always going to have agencies trying to make a dference and it is something we cannot close our eyes to.ldquoDferent levels of poverty exist throughout East Lothian.ldquoThere is no reason why people should suffer or worry about getting help when funds are available.ldquoI was talking to a couple of people about this and I am amazed more people have not applied.ldquoI am constantly keeping in contact with the dferent agencies to get them to spread the word to make them aware of it.ldquoIt is on the community council website andpeople are worried that their names are going to be discussed it would be breaking the community council code of conduct.ldquoWe would not be discussing anybodyrsquos name ndash it would be in the strictest of confidence.The cash grant cannot be used to purchase alcohol or tobacco, and all receipts must be ed to the person who has made the referral.The person making the referral should specy how much they think the inidual or family needs to assist them at the time.The community council, which also covers Athelstaneford, will then review the application, decide how much is to be awarded as a grant, and arrange for the person making the referral to be given the cash grant.Funding has been secured through area partnership European funding, and a donation from a Haddington resident, who asked to remain anonymous, in response to the community resilience teamrsquos efforts during lockdown.Volunteers from throughout the community joined forces to ensure help and assistance were on offer to vulnerable members of society.As well as collecting shopping and prescriptions, volunteers made face shields, delivered hot meals and even provided a service where people could simply chat to someone over the phone.The community resilience group also set up a lending library, which is continuing throughout the pandemic, where people can borrow jigsaws, books and games.Mrs Lemmon said: ldquoIt dawned on us there was a need, with winter coming in, to have a look at clothing.ldquoWe thought about a clothing exchange or clothing bank but there was just as much need for clothing grants as well as food grants.Already, more than pound, has been handed over, with the community councillor pleased to say there were ldquoa few thousand pounds still available.The scheme is open to anyone in the Haddington and Lammermuir ward. To find out more, email all@haddingtoncc.org.uk

title: hundred-tonnes-gravel-donated-gifford-community-woodland
story: The team behind Gford Community Woodland has struck up a partnership with Tillicoultry Quarries, which manages nearby Longyester Quarry.Neville Kilkenny, project manager at Gford Community Woodland, got in touch with the quarry with the hope of securing materials to help the drainage and improve accessibility to the villagersquos woodland.He was pleased to say that had proven successful and added: ldquoThe Community Woodland at Gford has become an important resource to the local and broader community for both health and wellbeing, as well as in terms of it being a fantastic example of a native broad leaf woodland in Scotland.ldquoHaving worked on the project for the last few years, it has been a wonderful experience in terms of bringing together and engaging the local community around this ancient forest.ldquoThe footfall within the woodland and on East Lothianrsquos path network has signicantly increased since the start of the Covid- pandemic, as many of our community use it as the main destination for daily recreational walks and outdoor exercise.ldquoThough the woods are a fantastic and hugely valuable asset, one of its central paths ndash an old railway line which is a key link between our woodland and other core path routes ndash has poor drainage, which is causing accessibility challenges for some of our older and less able visitors.ldquoWersquove also had challenges with drainage from this area, causing localised flooding.ldquoWith Longyester Quarry on our doorstep, enabling us to minimise our environmental impact, and having been a customer of Tillicoultry Quarries myself, I hoped to secure some much-needed local business support to reprofile and maintain the drainage ditches using perforated pipework backfilled with  tonnes of gravel.ldquoThey didnrsquot disappoint and we were delighted when they said yes.Tillicoultry Quarries, which was formed nearly  years ago, has  sites across Scotland. Wallace Menzies, director of the business, was delighted to help out.He said: ldquoThis is an important part of who we are as a company, as we know our successes are firmly rooted in the local communities which we work and live in.ldquoGiven the environmental importance of the work being done at Gford Community Woodland, its positive impacts on the local community ndash especially throughout Covid- ndash and with its proximity to our Longyester Quarry, we were only too pleased to offer our support.ldquoWe wish Neville and the local community in East Lothian the very best of luck in their endeavours with the woodland and look forward to seeing the project develop and add value to the local area for many years to come.

title: coronavirus-restrictions-east-lothian-moved-level-2
story: Speaking ahead of tomorrowrsquos review of the restrictions, Nicola Sturgeon told reporters that one council ldquomaybe more was being considered for a move down.And she pointed to her comments last week when she named a number of councilson the cusp of going down.She told reporters: ldquoIrsquoll refer you to the list from last week, East Lothian for example.The rate of infection in East Lothian is currently listed as . cases per , cases.Neighbouring Midlothianrsquos case rate has fallen even further to ., making it another council which could be arguing to come out of Level .Meanwhile Scottish Borders, which is in Level , has a . rate per ,.

title: east-lothian-move-level-2-coronavirus-restrictions-next-week
story: First Minister Nicola Sturgeon todaytold the Scottish Parliament that both East Lothian and Midlothian had seen enough improvement in infection rates to be taken down from Level  restrictions.She said that the restrictions that had been in place on household gatherings and hospitality had made a dference, adding that without action the number of cases which could have been reported daily in Scotland would be at , now.She said: ldquoI am pleased to report that East Lothian and Midlothian have both seen a marked decline in infection rates, prevalence in these areas is signicantly below the level for Scotland as a whole.ldquoOn that basis, assuming no signicant deterioration before then, I can confirm that East Lothian and Midlothian will move down from Level  to Level  from next Tuesday, November .In a slip of the tongue, the First Minister initially said "from Level  to Level " but quickly apologised and corrected herself.ON THE LEVEL: What can be done in Covid protection Level She added that the weeks wait before the change came into forcewould allow the two local authorities time to carry out additional health checks and work with NHS Lothian to ensure checks are in place.Among the changes, the move to Level  will allow hospitality businesses to serve alcohol indoors with main meals, up to pm, and beer gardens and outdoor areasto sell alcoholuntil .pm.Meanwhile,  local authority areas ndash mainly in the west ndash are being placed in Level , the highest level of restrictions, in a bid to bring down high infection rates. Glasgow, Stirling and West Lothian are among the council areas affected.

title: east-lothians-move-level-2-coronavirus-restrictions-welcomed
story: First Minister Nicola Sturgeon announced this afternoon that the county would see its restrictions relaxed from Level  to Level  from Tuesday of next week.And the news has been well received in East Lothian.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothians MP, said: "Delighted to hear that ndash progress being made and a respite for many sectors."However, people require to remain vigilant as wersquove seen how quickly the virus can escalate."It was becoming wearisome but the sacrice is paying off. Letrsquos keep it that way.Meanwhile, East Lothians MSP Iain Gray described it as "very welcome news for everyone in East Lothian".He said: "It reflects the fact that the dedicated efforts of the council, businesses and the public over recent weeks have resulted in a downward trend in the infection rate here.ldquoBy following the public health guidance, we have been able to prove beyond doubt that we are ready for Level  and the eased restrictions that involves."That is great news for local businesses and workers, especially those in the hospitality industry.ldquoHowever, as the First Minister also rightly highlighted today, we must not let down our guard now."We have to remain vigilant and continue to follow the rules and restrictions to avoid undermining the progress that has been made so far, keep protecting the vulnerable and enable us to look forward to better days ahead.Councillor Norman Hampshire, depute leader of East Lothian Council, stressed that a lot of work had gone on behind the scenes to reach the current situation.He was confident that businesses were well aware of the implicationsrestrictions were not adhered to and was hopeful that East Lothian would remain in Level .He said: "The whole situation is in our hands."If we adhere to the guidance then infection rates should stay lowwe ignore the guidance then infection rates will rise and move back up to a more restrictive tier."Among the changes, the move to Level  will allow hospitality businesses to serve alcohol indoors with main meals up to pm, and beer gardens and outdoor areas to sell alcoholuntil .pm.Stuart Broomfield, manager of the Waterside Bistro in Haddington, said: ldquoItrsquos fantastic news for us, obviously."Therersquos been a lot of hard work and effort put in over the weeks and months, and itrsquos nice to see, particularly for East Lothian, that the numbers are coming down and things are heading in the right direction.ldquoIt would be nice to think we could get that down to Level  but wersquoll have to wait and see what happens but generally, yes, very happy with Level  and fingers crossed things move forward in a positive way.ldquoAll round, itrsquos very positive news for the area and for the county.Dominic Campanile, from The Old Clubhouse in Gullane, was ldquodelighted with the latest announcement and said: ldquoThis is the best as could be expected.Mr Campanile described the initial shutdown as ldquoan absolute nightmare but, since the business had reopened, trade had not been as bad as it could have been.Now, following Tuesdayrsquos announcement, he was pleased to say it was a real boost.Mr Campanile added: ldquoAlmost since the announcement, we have had local customers on the phone booking tables.ldquoThere is obviously an appetite to get back out.

title: coronavirus-christmas-scotland-nicola-sturgeon-confirms-uk-wide-plan-festive-period
story: Reports earlier this morning suggested that health chiefs are looking at how to relax restrictions to allow for more ldquonormality over the festive period.The Sun reports that plans are in place which may mean a rule change for a few days around December .Speaking at her daily coronavirus briefing, the First Minister confirmed the Scottish Government is in discussion with the rest of the UK to create a four-nations consensus.Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoWe are all desperate for some normality around Christmas and I absolutely include myself in that.ldquoThe Scottish Government right now is working very closely and well with the other UK nations to try to agree a way for that to happen ndash we want to have the same position across the UK given family patterns that exist.ldquoBut we know that people coming together when a virus is circulating will increase the risks of it spreading.The First Minister again said that meeting at Christmas requires the prevalence of the virus to reduce in the coming weeks.A Downing Street spokesman confirmed to the Sun: ldquoWe are looking at ways to ensure that people can spend time with close family over Christmas at the end of what has been an incredibly dficult year.

title: green-energy-project-proposed-former-cockenzie-power-station-site
story: The proposals for the former Cockenzie Power Station site would create hundreds of jobs and see the entire site, which was bought by the local authority from ScottishPower, brought back into use.But it has drawn concern from Prestonpans Community Council, which points out that a masterplan for the site predicts it has potential for , jobs ndash far more than the project would deliver.Edinburgh-based development management company Composium Group Ltd has set out their proposals for the site, which would create an energy centre to house water-source heat pumps served with seawater from below the seabed of the Firth of Forth.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothian MP, has revealed that he has met with the consortium and is supporting the bid at a ldquonational as well as local level.Mr MacAskill said: ldquoIrsquove met representatives of this consortium and think that therersquos huge potential in their scheme.ldquoItrsquos obviously of national, not just local, signicance and Irsquom seeking a meeting for them with ministers. It has the opportunity to build on the countyrsquos past and current energy source and provide employment in a manner that will enhance, not detract from the environment.ldquoThere requires to be consultation locally but it certainly has potential.The only approved plans for the site are for Inch Cape Offshore Limitedrsquosplanned substation to bring offshore energy onto land.That proposal was decided by Scottish Ministers, who called in the planning application before East Lothian Council had ruled on it.The company at the heart of the latest plans confirmed it would take up all of the former power station footprint, with the exception of the space set aside for ICOLrsquos substation.Iain Gray, East Lothian MSP, said whatever proposal brought forward for Cockenzie had to benefit the local communities.Vitally importantHe said: ldquoThe former Cockenzie Power Station site is at the heart of economic development opportunities in East Lothian.ldquoItrsquos vitally important that the site is developed in a way thatrsquos sustainable and right for local communities, as well as delivering new jobs and greater prosperity for the whole county.ldquoI know there are a number of potential proposals emerging, including this one.ldquoEast Lothian Council, as owners of the site, will eventually have to make decisions on the sitersquos future and what will bring most benefit. However, that work is currently being held up by the Scottish Governmentrsquos delay in progressing the new National Planning Framework.ldquoThe council has presented a strong vision for Cockenzie and the wider area, including Blindwells, to be designated a National Development and a Climate Change Zone, which would open up an exciting range of possibilities.Brian Weddell, Prestonpans Community Council chairperson, said: ldquoPrestonpans Community Council looks forward to engaging with the consortium on their proposals for the former power station site at Preston Links.ldquoInitial concerns have already been expressed that this plan appears to encroach on the Greenhills, which is a popular area on the foreshore used by many local people.ldquoWe also would like much more detail on the potential for local jobs.ldquoThe Cockenzie Masterplan, published three years ago, outlined that the site could provide over , jobs and, in the current economic climate, the local community desperately needs new employment initiatives and we would seek details on the jobs that they say they could deliver.Bryan Hickman, Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council chairperson, said that the group would want to see more on the plans before offering a detailed opinion but described the green energy project as a ldquopromising start.At the heart of the latest project is UK company TELESIS Synergy Systems Limited, which plans to provide ldquogreen, clean, innovative energy on site.The initial energy would be used to heat a -hectare horticultural operation which would see greenhouses built on the former coal plant site, as well as providing energy for a green data centre on the footprint of the power station itself.Phase two of the proposals reveals plans to extend the energy centre to create low-cost, low-carbon, heating for local housing.It is claimed the project would create  jobs in the development of phase one and up to  jobs permanently once phase one is complete.Jon Harkins, business development director of TELESIS Synergy Systems, said: ldquoGreen, clean utility supplies such as those we are proposing to provide at Cockenzie will be the  for operations and employment on that site for many generations to come.ldquoThe geothermal qualities of the naturally puried water we acquire from below the seabed of the Firth of Forth is obtained through a system that has a lecycle that is measured in hundreds of years.Ron Daniel, CEO of Composium Group Ltd, said: ldquoWe have a few of the big boys interested in being involved in this project, household names. The proposition ticks many boxes.ldquoCockenzie presents an unparalleled opportunity for a green development in that there is not only a National Grid substation on the site but also the same site is the delivery point of a renewablesupplyof which we require a MWsupply.A council spokesperson said: ldquoWe are aware of a proposal for the former Cockenzie Power Station site and are awaiting more detail. No formal plans have been submitted at this stage.

title: mekala-osborne-able-return-home-15-months
story: Mekala Osborne was given just a five per cent chance of survival after falling ill while travelling in Asia last year.Now, after  months away from home, her family are getting ready to welcome the former Preston Lodge High School pupil home.Her mum, Yvonne McAulay, was lost for words.She told the Courier: ldquoIt is hard to explain."Irsquom absolutely over the moon but Irsquom scared because it has been such a long time.ldquoTo get her home for Christmas is the best Christmas present ever.ldquoThis time last year, Christmas was cancelled we are absolutely over the moon now.ldquoShe is coming on well but there is a long, long, long way to go.Mekala, who is currently in hospital in Edinburgh, took to social media todayafternoon to confirm the exciting news.She said: ldquoAfter a successful home assessment and family meeting, I have a discharge date!!ldquoThe countdown is on.ldquoI cannot bloody wait to be reunited with my friends n family!!!ldquoThe th of December is very signicant date to me which is why I chose it in particular as my discharge date.ldquoIt is my Paparsquos birthday and is the date I have tattooed on my ribs in memory of him.ldquoEvery time I see these scars, I also see my Papa and I remember the strength he gave me.ldquoI want to say a massive thank you again to all who have supported me all the way, I canrsquot wait to be out in the community again and seeing everyone!Mekala left the family home on Wallyfordrsquos Dury Way, which she shares with her mum and step-dad Jimmy, as well as brother Danny, at the beginning of September .She had only been in south-east Asia for a matter of weeks before she took unwell.Initially, the keen hockey player was complaining of a sore throat but it soon became clear that it was much more serious and she was put in an induced coma in Vietnam.Members of the community rallied round to support the family and raised thousands of pounds to help cover medical and travel costs.Yvonne, who described the community support as ldquophenomenal, flew out to be with her daughter and Mekala, who contracted necrotising pneumonia, was transferred to a hospital in Singapore before finally getting back to Scotland in November last year.Since then, the -year-old has been undergoing a gruelling rehabilitation and was allowed to visit her house last Thursday, along with NHS staff.Her mum, who works as a bus driver for Harlawhill Day Care Centre in Prestonpans, said: ldquoEven when the car was pulling up, I had to ask lsquois this happening rsquoldquoI had to pinch myself and I was just so emotional.ldquoI just lost it and was howling.Experts had to check the house was suitable for Mekala, who is a qualied personal trainer, tohome on a permanent basis.That saw Mekala visit the ious rooms in the property, including her bedroom, where she was able to lie back on her bed.Only Yvonne was allowed in the house at the time of the visit due to coronavirus restrictions and when Mekala gets tohome it will be the first time she has seen her brother, who is autistic, for more than a year.Yvonne, , added: ldquoIt has only been by FaceTime.ldquoShe has never seen her brother since September  last year.ldquoHe came to the airport with us and saw her going away but that was the last time she physically held him.

title: coronavirus-300-pupils-east-lothian-self-isolate-since-return
story: But they said that that number was lower than other parts of the country.Dr Lynne Binnie, East Lothian Councilrsquos principal educational psychologist, told a meeting of the local authorityrsquos education committee that social distancing and cleaning measures in schools has kept the number of pupils out of school for Covid reasons ldquorelatively low.And she said that the councilrsquos safeguarding policy and approach to ing youngsters to school had been praised by the NHS Health Protection Teams set up to scrutinise schools.She said: ldquoWe are seeing a relatively small number of children having to self-isolate, in term two it is  pupils.ldquoWe feel the risk managementwe have in placeis keeping the number low.The -pupils figure represents less than two per cent of the countyrsquos school roll, which stood at , in September ndash half the national average of pupils absent from classes for Covid reasons.And school attendance overall remains high at . per cent, compared to  per cent nationally.Lesley Brown, head of education and childrenrsquoswellbeing, told the virtual meeting of the committee that strict social distancing and class bubbles had avoided whole classes having to be sent homea child tested positive.She said: ldquoIf a Covid case is identied as positive, the contact tracing is done.ldquoWe have to look at who has been within two metres of contact that tends to mean, with our social distancing measures, a small number of children and staff have to self-isolate.Councillor Willie Innes, council leader, gave credit to everyone involved, from headteachers to education officers, teachers and cleaning teams.He said: ldquoI think sometimes the unsung heroes are the cleaning staff. We do not always give them the praise they deserve. I think we have to recognise the incredible work they do.In the past week, positive cases of coronavirus have been recorded at Athelstaneford, Dirleton, Dunbar and Stoneyhill Primary Schools, Musselburgh Grammar School and Ross High School in Tranent.

title: misunderstanding-saw-man-drive-musselburgh-disqualified
story: Nicodema Masecchia, of Kidlaw Cottages, near Gford, was stopped in his car by police officers on mobile patrol at about .pm on July .Edinburgh Sherf Court was told that Masecchia provided a provisional licence but, following checks, it was found he was disqualied from driving following a previous offence.Officers also contacted the -year-oldrsquos insurance company and it was found there was no valid cover on the vehicle.He was arrested and charged and appeared at the Capital court along with an interpreter last Tuesday, where he pleaded guilty to the two offences.Solicitor George Henry said that his client had been banned from driving for six months in January and Masecchia had made a mistake as he ldquothought the ban was up.Mr Henry said that the January ban still had  days to run when he was pulled over by police at Linkfield Road in Musselburgh in July.The lawyer added that Masecchia, an unemployed chef, lived in ldquoa rural location and his licence ldquois very important to him.He said: ldquoHe does have a number of analogous convictions but this does seem to be a genuine mistake.Sherf Campbell said: ldquoFrom what I have been told, this has arisen from a misunderstanding of a court order.ldquoThat is extremely unfortunate but I am prepared to deal with this matter on the basis of the plea.ldquoThere will be no ban but the court will not be so generous in future.The sherf placed six penalty points on the Italian nationalrsquos driving licence and fined him pound.Masecchia pleaded guilty to driving a vehicle while disqualied and with no insurance at Linkfield Road, Musselburgh, on July .

title: iain-gray-msp-holes-coronavirus-support
story: Last week, this issue came to the fore at both the Scottish and UK Parliaments. At Holyrood, Scottish Labour tabled a motion calling on the Scottish Government to provide additional support for tourism and hospitality. Our motion, which mandated ministers to take action to protect jobs, livelihoods and the future of the industry, was passed and they should now act immediately.We are also highlighting the dire circumstances facing taxi drivers, many of whom have played a vital role in fighting the pandemic. Many have fallen into debt and face the prospect of losing their livelihoods unless rules governing existing schemes are changed.Across the UK, there are an estimated three million self-employed workers who have often struggled to access Government financial support. Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer highlighted their plight at last weekrsquos PMQs and urged the Prime Minister and Chancellor to address the injustice facing these ldquoexcluded workers.These workers cover a vast range of people, including new starters, those in between jobs, those denied furlough, the newly self-employed and new businesses, those earning less than  per cent of their income from self-employment, and a whole range of other personal circumstances affecting eligibility through no fault of their own.With many months of restrictions likely still ahead of us, this issue is not going away. It is a matter of fairness and justice, and Governments in Edinburgh and London must do more.

title: special-cairn-remembrance-created-north-berwick
story: pARTicipate, an arts group based in the town, joined North Berwick Community Counciland North Berwick Rotary Club to make the installation and a cairn of remembrance.It is the third installation created by pARTicipate to mark remembrance its first, in , marked the centenary of the First World War and another, in , used paintings of poppies and doves to mark absent friends.This yearrsquos installation was created by members of the community and can be seen for the rest of the month in the Telephone Exchange public arts space on Westgate.Current coronavirus restrictions made planning the new artwork a challenge but Hilary Smith, chair of the local area partnership, facilitated a virtual discussion between NBCC chair Judy Lockhart, Bass Rock Community Group volunteer and North Berwick Rotary Club member Richard Rogers, and pARTicipate co-ordinator Geraldine Prince.New Rotary group the Bass Rock Community Group developed the idea of a remembrance cairn and Richard contacted the local area partnership after the community council decided a painted pebble cairn was unsuitable for the war memorial gardens.Richard said: ldquoNational concerns about gatherings of large groups meant that the usual armistice parade and wreath-laying could not take place, so we looked at alternative ways for the community to show their respect.Hilary Smith reminded me that pARTicipate had created a memory cairn last year as a feature in North Berwickrsquos lsquocompassionate communitiesrsquo activities.ldquoIt offered an opportunity to pool our creative resources at this challenging time. We are particularly keen to get children and young people to add a pebble painted with the name of someone they wish to remember and place it on the cairn.Geraldine added: ldquoDue to the pandemic restrictions, we were unable to organise any arts workshops this year but, happily, I had kept the poppies and the doves that were made for last yearrsquos installation.ldquoVolunteer Hope Johnston used her creative skills to repair, restore or remake poppies from the  installation, meticulously repainting the inidual poppy leaves.ldquoWith input from volunteer Gary Watson, we assembled a simple but, we hope, dignied collage representation of a poppy wreath with falling poppies to each side.ldquoIt enables the old telephone kiosks to play their part in offering a moment of reflection at a time when our horizons are temporarily very limited.ldquoIt was rewarding to be able to re-use, or recycle, last yearrsquos poppies so that, in these exceptional times, the communityrsquos creative talents are still represented.ldquoAlthough we could involve only three volunteers this year due to social distancing, in fact there are many hands at work in this installation to complement the cairn.Judy said: ldquoI was happy to support both the Rotary Bass Rock Community Group and pARTicipate by contributing to the design and also enabling NBCC to co-operate with other groups in paying our respects.And now residents are being encouraged to paint a poppy, or the name of someone they would like to remember, onto a pebble and lay it at the displayrsquos cairn of remembrance at the arts space, which previously was home to public telephone cabins.

title: virtual-event-aims-showcase-best-east-lothian-tour-operators
story: Scotland Reconnect  takes place from Monday to Wednesday and offers international travel agents the opportunity to connect and do business with Scottish suppliers online.Events including VisitScotlandrsquos annual Expo travel trade showcase and programmes of business development missions have been rendered impossible by Covid- restrictions.New digital s, like Reconnect, have been developed and will see some  buyers undertake virtual meetings with about  Scottish tourism businesses, including Visit East Lothian.Elaine Carmichael, from Visit East Lothian, said: ldquoWe are looking forward to showcasing East Lothian to the travel trade at Scotland Reconnects.ldquoIt is vitally important that we are working to do all that we can to support our industry at this time and planning and looking to future opportunities is a key part of this.ldquoIt is encouraging to see the number and iety of buyers looking to engage and seeking to develop their knowledge and offer.ldquoThis event gives us the opportunity to ensure that East Lothian is front of mind and is included as part of that offer when the time is right to travel and visit Scotland again.Buyers from the USA, Canada, Germany, France, Italy, Spain, Holland, Scandinavia, Australia and Brazil are attending Scotland Reconnect , as well as London-based inbound operators representing the Japanese and Chinese markets.#In addition to facilitating some , business meetings, there will also be live webinars, round table discussions and breakout sessions, an online presentation hub and virtual experiences demonstrating what Scotland can offer buyersrsquo clients.John Thurso, VisitScotlandrsquos chairman, will open and close Scotland Reconnect .#

title: polar-tour-guide-tells-tale-exceptional-fossilist-mary-anning
story: The scientist, who moved to Haddington two years ago, has published The Fossil Woman, a biography of the ldquomost famous person many of us had never heard of ndash fossilist Mary Anning ndash drawing on his own expertise and love of the subject.Mary Anning was born in Lyme Regis, Dorset, in , the daughter of a cabinet maker.Her father supplemented his meagre income by selling fossils found on the Lyme Regis coast to tourists, and taught his children to do the same.He died when Mary was aged  but she and her older brother Joseph continued to find, clean and sell the fossils.But Mary went further, studying her finds and learning about geology and palaeontology, at a time when such sciences were still in their infancy.Tom said: ldquoShe was quite exceptional.ldquoShe wasnrsquot the only woman collecting fossils at the time but almost all the other women who were involved in palaeontology in some way were middle class, or upper class or gentry they were amateurs, or many of them were married to geologists.ldquoBut Mary was poor, working class and she was selling fossils.ldquoSo she was arguably one of the first professional geologists in the world.Tom told the Courier: ldquoPeople were coming to Lyme Regis to see her, to learn from her, to buy specimens for museums and universities and for their own private collections.Tom, originally from Rutherglen, studied geology at the University of Glasgow before moving to Wales and becoming the curator of palaeontology at National Museum Wales.He has taught geology at the Universities of Cardf and Bristol and has worked in expedition travel since , travelling mainly in the Arctic, Antarctic, North Atlantic and Patagonia.He was approached to write the biography of Mary Anning by The Dovecote Press publishing company, which wanted to set the record straight ahead of a biopic of the geologist, called Ammonite and starring Kate Winslet, which is due for a big screen release next year.The film, directed by Francis Lee, alludes to a love affair between Mary and Charlotte Murchison ndash which Tom said is unlikely to have happened.ldquoCharlotte Murchison is portrayed as being a young woman suffering from melancholy, Tom said, ldquoand actually Charlotte was  years older than Mary Anning.ldquoAnd then therersquos an odd reference in a letter from Mary to Charlotte as to how attractive she finds [Charlottersquos] husband.ldquoMaryrsquos talking about reports she had heard about Murchison giving a lecture somewhere, and how great it was, and this Mary could believe, lsquobecause hersquos the handsomest piece of flesh and blood I ever saw!rsquoWhatever the fiction built up around Mary Anning, Tom believes she was one of the most signicant women in the history of Britain.He said: ldquoShe certainly hasnrsquot had the recognition that she deserves.ldquoI mean, she should be up there with the great women of the th century: people like Florence Nightingale and Jane Austen.And as for that East Lothian ammonite  Itrsquos a Jurassic fossil from Portland, Dorset, the sort that is quarried ldquoto use as a garden ornament, said Tom, and can be found embedded in a block of limestone in the ground next to Gosford Housersquos curling house.ldquoI was absolutely gobsmacked to find a Jurassic ammonite in East Lothian, said Tom.ldquoUnfortunately itrsquos not in situ so I canrsquot make my scientic reputation on that basis!The Fossil Woman: A Le Of Mary Anning is available to buy now via www.dovecotepress

title: tyninghame-beach-makes-onto-top-10-sounds-british-outdoors-list
story: Compiled by outdoor equipment brand Cotswold Outdoor, in partnership with wildle field recordist Pete Smith and Helen Glover MBE, double-Olympic gold medallist in rowing, the top- list sees ldquothe sound of wind blowing through the grass at sand dunes at Tyninghame Beach at number eight.Mr Smith, a sound designer who lives just outside Edinburgh, said: ldquoTo me, sound is everything, so it has been interesting how people have tuned into the sounds of their surroundings more than ever throughout .He added: ldquoIt was the year that everything stopped and, as the traffic noise quietened during lockdown and our streets fell silent, the sounds of the outdoors became acutely more noticeable.Pete spent two days in the field, prior to the latest lockdown measures, capturing examples of sounds for the top  list for Cotswold Outdoor, as well as sourcing sounds from his archive and other libraries.Helen added: ldquoI will always enjoy coastal walks accompanied by the ebb and flow of the tide, particularly on a stormy day when the waves are roaring and crashing.The crunching of autumn leaves underfoot topped the list of the best sounds of the natural world identied by the team, with rain on a tent in the Scottish Highlands at number four.The sounds are all now available to listen to at www.cotswoldoutdoor soundon

title: coronavirus-scotland-vaccine-scottish-governments-plan-priority-list-explained
story: HealthSecretaryJeane Freeman said the Scottish Government plans to vaccinate . million Scots over the age of  in the coming months.She said ministershoped to begin the vaccination programme in the first week of December, with , doses expected that month.Ms Freeman said: "Scotland has an excellent track record of vaccinations."But this is to be one of the biggest civilian logistical challenges in our letime."When will the first wave of vaccination take place Ministers hope the delivery programme will take from December until spring next year to complete.The first wave will be carried out from December to February.Who will be prioritised The Scottish Governmentrsquos priority for the vaccination is as follows: Those aged over and those under  who are at an additional clinical risk will then vaccinated, before it is offered to the wider population.What has the Scottish Government said Ms Freeman saidScotlandwill need more than , vaccinators and support staff by the end of January.This means around one million people will be able to vaccinated by that time.She said:"We are hopeful that over the coming weeks into  we will have more than one vaccine available to us, so that we can, with minimum delay, vaccinate as many people as possible as quickly as possible."However Ms Freemanstressed there are still a number of unknowns, such as which vaccines will be approved for use.The Scottish Government hopes to be able to vaccinate in locations such as GP practices and care homes.Some people could be vaccinated at homenecessary.Ms Freeman said the first vaccines will require two doses three to four weeks apart."Its possible that further booster doses and even an annual programme might be required," she said.

title: take-first-steps-fix-finances
story: Take the first steps to fix your financesThe current pandemic has caused some who struggle to feel even more financial prltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtessure, and others hltspan classtruncate-full-screengtave been suddenly thrown into a world ofWide-ranging restrictions on all our lives have led to a wave of redundancies and financial uncertainty, with the unfortunate likelihood that there will be many more job losses over the months to come.This economic catastrophe means that many people, even those who have never previously had money worries, might find themselves in a position where they fall into debt while trying to make ends meet. But while the situation sounds bleak, the good news is that there is plenty of support out there for anyone who needs it.Debt charity StepChange has been delivering free debt advce in Scotland since , with a team of sympathetic and knowledgeable advisors ready to help those who are in financial trouble. ldquoI think itrsquos very important for people to understand that they are not alone, stresses Sharon Bell, Head of StepChange Scotland.ldquoWe all take out credit at dferent times in our lives, whether it is to buy a new car, a house, to purchase something. In normal situations you will make your payments and pay back that credit ndash but your circumstances can change over time.ldquoWhether it is because you have had a cut in your working hours, or yoursquove lost your job, or suddenly your costs have increased and money is more dficult to manage. Irrespective of your type of debt we would look at all your debt and your income and expenditure and look at what options are out there that are available for you.ldquoWe will help you understand what your options are.ldquoYou could be in arrears on your rent or behind on your electric bill but what we will do is look at the dferent types of debt you have and whether you can manage that debt better, orit has to be looked at as a potential write-off.You might be reading this while thinking you would never let yourself fall into debt, presuming it is something that only happens to other people. But according to Sharon, debt is a very subjective issue.ldquoSomebody can owe a family member pound, and that could be really important to them. They could be really worried, and really stressing, about the fact they are in debt for pound.ldquoThere are other people who could have loans or credit card bills that constitute multiple thousands of pounds ndash butthey are able to manage these payments then debt isnrsquot a problem.ldquoThe problems start coming when you are not able to make your repayments, and you start to feel stressed. If you are feeling stressed about the money you owe, you have what we would call lsquoproblem debtrsquo and you should get help and advice as quickly as possible.ldquoThe sooner you get help and advice, the quicker and easier it will be to deal with that debt. If you delay, charges and interest could be applied to that debt and it could snowball and become a much bigger problem.Evenyou donrsquot personally find yourself in debt, it is important not to blame those who do. Sharon points out that while society often assumes that people in financial dficulty have been lsquorecklessrsquo with their money, most have simply been impacted by le events that are outwith their control.ldquoOne of the things that is particularly evident now with Covid is making people more conscious of the fact that money is dficult, and they are more willing to speak about debt. And I donrsquot think anybody should be scared to speak about debt with loved ones, friends, or with an organisation like StepChange.ldquoWe are here to help, not to make judgements, only to help you deal with your circumstances. Most people have had debt, or some financial dficulty, at some point in their lives.Sharon has a team of  trained money advisors working in the StepChange Glasgow office. Theyrsquove even introduced a dedicated Covid payment plan, a short-term solution to help those whose financial situation has been negatively affected by the coronavirus pandemic.Itrsquos designed for those who perhaps werenrsquot in financial dficulty before March, but as a direct influence of Covid they find themselves in a dficult spot. It is designed to help people through and give them breathing space, according to Sharon. ldquoThe pandemic has caused some who struggle to struggle even more, whereas for others they have been thrown into the world of debt that they never thought they would be in.And Irsquom sure it will be a very distressing time, with uncertainty about jobs and outgoings, it causes a lot of stress. ldquoYoursquove got a pandemic which is impacting on peoplersquos health and wellbeing, when you add financial stress into that peoplersquos wellbeing can get even worse.Fortunately, whatever your circumstances, the team at StepChange are on hand to offer free, non-judgemental advice to anyone in need.Get online advice now at www. stepchange.org scotland or call

title: covid-travel-restrictions-scotland-force-today
story: After the new coronavirus rules were branded nonsensical and many Scots were left feeling confused, The Scottish Government published guidance which outlined howthose living in a tier  or  council area ldquoare now required to stay in that area unless they have a reasonable excuse to travel.:Rules branded nonsensical as Scots banned from airports but not flights abroadThose who are caught violating the new rules, could face a pound fine, which rises topoundnot paid within  days.Here is everything you need to know about the latest travel restrictions coming into force from this evening.In a list published by the Scottish Government, reasonssuch as travelling to and from work unable to work from home, travelling for education, and "essential shopping" are cited as "reasonable".:Travel ban exemptions published amid legal questionsThese include the following:Travel restrictions are now enforceable by law - which means the police can distribute pound fines to those caught breaching the rules.This amount can increase to poundnot paid within  days, and repeat offenders could face penalties of up to pound.:Police to enforce travel ban in tier  and  areasHowever, Police Scotland has stated that there will be no road blocks orroutine stops of vehicles, and has asked that people continue to but asked people to ldquotake personal responsibility over the new restrictions.Public transport will continue to run as normal, with face mask and social distancing rules observed when travelling.However, people in restricted areas have again been asked to limit their journeys and should only use public transport"essential."The Scottish Government has also stated that motorists should avoid carsharing with anyone who is not in their own household.For people living in tier one or tier two areas, it is a requirement to avoid travelling to level three or four restrictions.That said, travel to other tier one and tier two areas can continue, as long as the other guidelines are followed.However,you live in a tier three or four area, it is now a legal requirement to remain within your own council area - unless you have one of the "reasonable excuses" listed above.Those living in tier four must also be mindful of keeping journeys to an absolute minimum.Holidays are considered non-essential, and therefore those living in tier three or four areas should not go on holiday.:Nicola Sturgeon confirms dying mum can go on final holidayPeople living in tier one and two have also been strongly advised not to travel abroad, unless it is essential - however it is still legal for them to go on holiday and travel to airports or other travel stations.There are still -day quarantine periods in place for travellers arriving into Scotland from thecountries apart from those on the Scottish Governments exempt list.

title: fitness-classes-return-east-lothian-sports-centres-tuesday
